title: 113_s1000
content: The Act titled "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2014" defines key terms such as Administrator, Chesapeake Bay State, Chesapeake Bay watershed, and Chesapeake Executive Council. The Act includes states like Maryland, West Virginia, Delaware, New York, Virginia, Pennsylvania, and the District of Columbia within the Chesapeake Bay State. The Chesapeake Bay watershed encompasses all tributaries, backwaters, and side channels draining into the Chesapeake Bay. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act defines terms like "chief executive" and "Director." It also explains "Federal restoration activity" as programs or projects aimed at protecting, conserving, or restoring resources in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Projects in the Chesapeake Bay watershed receive financial and technical assistance for responsible land use, stewardship, and community engagement. Federal restoration activities are categorized into physical restoration, planning, feasibility studies, scientific research, monitoring, education, and infrastructure development. State restoration activities refer to State programs or projects that protect, conserve, or restore living resources, habitat, water resources, or water quality in the watershed. The Director, in consultation with relevant bodies, submits a financial report to Congress with an interagency crosscut budget for Federal restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Categories include physical restoration, planning, feasibility studies, scientific research, monitoring, education, and infrastructure development. The Director submits a financial report to Congress detailing funding for Federal and State restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed over a three-year period. The report includes planned funding for the next fiscal year, past expenditures, and an evaluation of restoration needs. The Director submits a financial report to Congress detailing funding for Federal and State restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed over a three-year period, including opportunities to consolidate programs and activities, detailed accounting of funds, and descriptions of proposed Federal and State actions. The Director provides a detailed report to Congress on funding for Federal and State restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including project descriptions, current status, funding history, risks, and alignment with the Chesapeake Bay Agreement. The Director's report to Congress on Chesapeake Bay restoration activities must align with the Chesapeake Bay Agreement, Executive Council goals, and Annual Action Plan. It specifies minimum funding levels for Federal and State projects, with amounts set at $300,000 for the first 3 years and $100,000 thereafter. The Director must submit a report to Congress by September 30 each year, detailing restoration activities with funding amounts over $100,000. Copies of the report will be sent to specific House and Senate committees. An Independent Evaluator will oversee restoration activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. The Independent Evaluator appointed by the Administrator from nominees submitted by the Chesapeake Executive Council will review and report on restoration activities and related topics suggested by the Council. The Evaluator must demonstrate excellence in marine science, policy evaluation, or related fields. The Independent Evaluator appointed by the Administrator will review and report on restoration activities and related topics suggested by the Chesapeake Executive Council. The Evaluator must demonstrate excellence in marine science, policy evaluation, or related fields. Reports must be submitted to Congress every 2 years.
